data.event: The beginnings of La Plata can be traced back to March 17, 1827 when Drury Davis established a trading post near the town's current location.
The ensuing few years saw Davis joined by family and friends to create a small village that included a blacksmith shop, an inn, and stagecoach station.
Gex won out and the town is believed to have been first incorporated on September 29, 1856.
The North Missouri (later known as the Wabash Railroad) came to town in 1867, and the Santa Fe Railroad twenty years later, passing through La Plata on its route from Chicago to Kansas City.

event.title: was incorporated as a fourth-class city on April 4, 1881

data.event: As part of this growth, the town was incorporated as a fourth-class city on April 4, 1881 with Jacob Gilstrap serving as first mayor.
La Plata's first major industry, a creamery, was established in 1883.

event.title: pass through La Plata as well, the Prairie Pipeline being the first in 1912

data.event: Two major oil pipelines pass through La Plata as well, the Prairie Pipeline being the first in 1912.
A "tank farm" of large storage tanks was located for many years on the city's northern edge.
